metadata.name: Legal Jurisdiction & Authority Logic
metadata.description: Decision matrix for determining regulatory authority based on land status, funding, and activity triggers
metadata.purpose: Distinguish ownership from regulatory jurisdiction (Federal Nexus)

federal_lands_surface.primary_authority: Federal Land Management Agency (USFS, BLM, NPS, USFWS)
federal_lands_surface.state_authority_overlay: State environmental laws often apply via 'Savings Clauses' or cooperative federalism (e.g., CWA Section 401)
federal_lands_surface.key_preemption_rule: Federal law preempts state law where conflict exists, but states can often be stricter

state_lands.primary_authority: State Land Management Agency (State Parks, SLC)
state_lands.federal_authority_overlay: Federal layout ONLY if Federal Nexus exists (ESA, CWA, Federal Funding)

private_lands.federal_authority_overlay: Apply ONLY if Federal Nexus exists (Waters of US, Listed Species, Federal Funding)

tribal_lands_trust.state_authority: Generally limited; PL-280 states have some criminal/civil jurisdiction but limited regulatory power

federal_nexus_triggers.description: Conditions that trigger federal jurisdiction on non-federal land

triggers.condition: Project receives ANY federal funding (grants, loans, cost-share)
triggers.consequence: NEPA compliance required (Lead Federal Agency must analyze)

triggers.condition: Discharge of dredged or fill material into Waters of the United States (WOTUS)
triggers.consequence: US Army Corps of Engineers permit required + NEPA + ESA Section 7

triggers.condition: Take of Federally Listed Species (on private land)
triggers.consequence: ESA Section 10 Incidental Take Permit (HCP) OR Section 7 if other federal nexus exists
common_examples: Timber harvest in spotted owl territory

triggers.condition: Action requiring federal approval or on federal land
triggers.consequence: Full federal compliance suite (NEPA, NHPA, ESA)
common_examples: Special Use Permit on National Forest

state_jurisdiction_triggers_california.description: Conditions triggering California state jurisdiction regardless of land ownership

triggers.condition: Alteration of bed, bank, or channel of ANY stream (ephemeral, intermittent, perennial)
triggers.scope: Applies to private, state, and local public lands; federal agencies may assert immunity but often coordinate

triggers.condition: Any federal license/permit that may result in discharge to waters
triggers.scope: State has veto power over federal permits (e.g., 404)
Extremely strict regulation of land use

jurisdictional_conflict_resolution.rule_1_stricter_standard: Generally, the stricter environmental standard applies
jurisdictional_conflict_resolution.rule_2_federal_supremacy: Federal agencies on Federal land follow federal law primarily; state law application is complex/negotiated
jurisdictional_conflict_resolution.rule_3_private_land_layering: Private land is subject to Local Zoning AND State Regulation AND Federal Nexus (if present) - All layers must be satisfied
